title: 114_hr2899
content: The "Countering Violent Extremism Act of 2015" or the "CVE Act" authorizes the Office for Countering Violent Extremism within the Department of Homeland Security. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism appointed by the Secretary. Permanent staff with technical, media, communications, or marketing background will be assigned or hired for the office. Support for the office will be provided within various components of the Department. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established with the Assistant Secretary responsible for coordinating activities to counter violent extremism across all department components. This includes identifying risk factors contributing to violent extremism in US communities. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism in the Department of Homeland Security is established to coordinate activities to counter violent extremism in US communities. This includes identifying populations targeted by extremist propaganda, managing outreach activities, ensuring relevant information informs counter-extremism efforts, and developing a department-wide strategy for countering violent extremism. The Department of Homeland Security's strategy to counter violent extremism includes leveraging technology and social media for messaging and outreach activities. The Department of Homeland Security's strategy for countering violent extremism includes using cooperative agreements with various entities, respecting privacy and civil liberties, and developing metrics to evaluate programs. The Department of Homeland Security aims to identify new research requirements, assess extremist propaganda methods, and establish a counter-messaging program to combat radicalization and recruitment. The Department of Homeland Security is tasked with coordinating counter-messaging efforts against extremist propaganda through technology, social media, and other resources. They also lead in coordinating with other federal agencies, non-governmental organizations, and the Department of State on countering violent extremism activities. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism works with FEMA to provide guidance on grant usage and administers grant programs related to countering violent extremism. They also establish a memorandum of understanding outlining their roles in grant administration. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism, in coordination with FEMA and the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, establishes a grant program for community groups to create counter-messaging campaigns against violent extremism. The Department will provide an implementation plan for the grant program, including eligibility and application criteria, methodology for awarding grants, and monitoring of applications. Community groups ineligible for grants are those funding violent extremist activities as determined by the Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism. The Assistant Secretary for Countering Violent Extremism will submit an annual report to Congress for the next five fiscal years on the Office for Countering Violent Extremism, detailing the Department's programs, policies, budget, and staffing dedicated to countering violent extremism. The annual report to Congress will include funding amounts for departmental programs related to countering violent extremism, activities of the Office to cooperate with other departments, outcome-based metrics for evaluating program success, organizations the Department conducted outreach with, grants awarded, and training sponsored by the Department. The annual report to Congress will include details on personnel and funding levels for the Office countering violent extremism, analysis of Department activities in response to the threat environment, protection of civil rights and liberties, evaluation of grant program effectiveness, and incorporation of lessons from other government programs. In this section, violent extremism is defined as ideologically motivated terrorist activities. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Office for Countering Violent Extremism annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 allocated for the grant program. This section will terminate five years after enactment. The Office for Countering Violent Extremism is authorized $10,000,000 annually from 2016 to 2020, with $6,000,000 for the grant program.
